subNodes.conversationText: root

This person matched Astimund's description of the messenger in possession of the minister's letter. She was sitting in the corner of the common room watching the musician play.

She glanced up at <FirstName>.
<FirstName> looked away. <He/She> would observe her before approaching.

<FirstName> saw that she kept her distance from the other patrons and seemed perfectly at ease in her solitude. Indeed, a person running messages between this forlorn region and the capital would have to be. <He/She> decided the messenger was all business and not likely to let her guard down if <FirstName> tried being chummy.

At the messenger's feet, <he/she> saw a satchel of hard leather. It was closed. The minister's letter was likely inside.
[End.]
<FirstName> sat down close by and greeted her in a friendly way.
She returned a cordial salutation but didn't seem interested in talking.
"Lovely playing," <FirstName> said.
"It is," she agreed.
"I hope he plays 'Oh Dark Knight.' That's one of my favorites."
"If you'll excuse me --" The messenger had had her fill of the young witch's company and stood to go.
To this the messenger only nodded and smiled weakly before directing her attention back to the musician. She looked -- or wanted to look -- more absorbed by the music than ever.
<FirstName> changed tack. "I heard you were carrying messages to the capital. Is this true?"
"Yes. Do you have something for me to deliver?"
<FirstName> sat back and listened to the music, watching the messenger out of the corner of <his/her> eye.
<FirstName> sat back and listened to the music, watching the messenger out of the corner of <his/her> eye.
<He/She> set the crow to work.
<FirstName> gave up. It was too risky. Astimund's plan would likely fail anyway.
"I heard that you were carrying messages to the capital. Is this true?"
<FirstName> sat back and listened to the music, watching the messenger out of the corner of <his/her> eye.

<FirstName> saw that she kept her distance from the other patrons and seemed prefectly at ease in her solitude. Indeed, a person running messages between this forlorn region and the capital would have to be. Friendliness might not go very far. <He/She> decided the messenger was all business.

The witch also saw a satchel at her feet of hard leather. It was closed. <He/She> was almost certain that the minister's letter was inside,
<FirstName> sat back and listened to the music, watching the messenger out of the corner of <his/her> eye.

As the song went on, <FirstName> noticed that the satchel was only loosely fastened with leather lace. It would be impossible for <him/her> to open it undetected, but a simple matter for <his/her> familiar.
While the messenger was distracted, <FirstName> set <his/her> familiar to work.

Pharaoh disliked crowds almost as much as Knott did, so he came down from the witch's shoulder with reluctance. But come down he did, responding to the command that passed between them the way the hand obeys the head.

He made a show of looking for crumbs on the floor as he hopped toward the messenger's bag.
<FirstName> gave up. It was too risky. Astimund's plan would likely fail anyway.
"I heard that you were carrying messages to the capital. Is this true?"
"Yes. Do you have something for me to deliver?"
"I will," said the young witch, improvising. "How long will you be here?"

"Not long. I plan to leave when he's done playing for the day," she said, gesturing to the musician.

The young witch wondered when that would be. The musician seemed indefatigable. Still, he had to stop some time.
"Lovely playing," <FirstName> said.
"The roads are quite dangerous these days, you know."
"The woods are dangerous," said the messenger. "but the roads to the capital are safe, or only as dangerous as they usually are."
<FirstName> sat back and listened to the music, watching the messenger out of the corner of <his/her> eye.
<FirstName> sat back and listened to the music, watching the messenger out of the corner of <his/her> eye.
While the messenger was distracted, <FirstName> set <his/her> familiar to work.
<FirstName> gave up. It was too risky. Astimund's plan would likely fail anyway.
"No. Just a warning -- the roads are quite dangerous."
"The woods are dangerous," said the messenger. "but the roads to the capital are safe, or only as dangerous as they usually are."
[Continue.]
"If you'll excuse me --" The messenger had had her fill of the young witch's company and stood to go.
[Prithee Sleep, Prithee Slumber] But the young witch couldn't let her get away.

Witchcraft in this sort of situation ought to have been a last resort, and witchcraft in the common room of a busy inn was almost indefensible. But too much rested on the letter the messenger was taking to the capital.
[Continue.]

<FirstName> mouthed the words of the spell quietly. The messenger put her hand to her head as if lightheaded. Then she sat back down, put her head down on the table, and slept. If anyone noticed, they thought the solitary woman in the corner had been trying too hard to drink away her loneliness.
[Continue.]
The task was now simple.
[Continue.]
<FirstName> took the minister's letter from the messenger's satchel and replaced it with the forgery.
[Continue.]

A few minutes later, <FirstName> watched the messenger wake up. She shook her head, deploring her carelessness, and checked the satchel. All the messages were there. She checked her coinpurse and found nothing missing there, either. She sighed in relief.

Then she left.
[Continue.]

The young witch had done all <he/she> could. Whether the plan would work -- whether the news of the king's death would be delayed, and whether the diplomatic mission would continue on to Wan -- remained to be seen.
[End.]
[Continue.]
Now the young witch had only to send the other forgery to Enzibar.
[End.]

actions.a_parameter_1: Forged Letter of the Minister lost!

subNodes.conversationText: There was nothing the witch could do.
A few minutes later, the young witch watched her leave. If the fate of Dudow rested on that letter, it was sealed.
She directed her attention back to the musician. She looked -- or wanted to look -- more absorbed by the music than ever.
"Lovely playing," <FirstName> said.
<FirstName> sat back and listened to the music, watching the messenger out of the corner of <his/her> eye.
<FirstName> sat back and listened to the music, watching the messenger out of the corner of <his/her> eye.
<He/She> set the crow to work.
<FirstName> gave up. It was too risky. Astimund's plan would likely fail anyway.
<FirstName> took a nearby seat as if to listen to the musician too.
<FirstName> gave up. It was too risky. Astimund's plan would likely fail anyway.
<FirstName> took a nearby seat as if to listen to the musician too.

<FirstName> watched the messenger. She kept her distance from the other patrons and seemed perfectly at ease in her solitude. Indeed, a person running messages between this forlorn region and the capital would have to be. <He/She> decided the messenger was all business and not likely to let her guard down if <FirstName> tried being chummy.

At the messenger's feet, <he/she> saw a satchel of hard leather. It was closed. The minister's letter was likely inside.
"Lovely playing," <FirstName> said.
"I heard that you were carrying messages to the capital. Is this true?"
<He/She> waited and continued watching.

As the song went on, <FirstName> noticed that the satchel was only loosely fastened with leather lace. It would be impossible for <him/her> to open it undetected, but a simple matter for <his/her> familiar.
<FirstName> gave up. It was too risky. Astimund's plan would likely fail anyway.
Once again, the young witch drew near the messenger.
<FirstName> sat down close by and greeted her in a friendly way.
<FirstName> took a nearby seat as if to listen to the musician too.
<FirstName> took a nearby seat as if to listen to the musician too.

As the song went on, <FirstName> noticed that the satchel was only loosely fastened with leather lace. It would be difficult for <him/her> to open it undetected, but it would be a simple matter for <his/her> familiar.
<FirstName> leaned over. "Lovely playing," <he/she> said to the messenger.
"It is," she agreed.
"I heard that you were carrying messages to the capital," <he/she> said, leaning over. "Is this true?"
"Yes. Do you have something for me to deliver?"
<He/She> set the crow to work.

Pharaoh disliked crowds almost as much as Knott did, so he came down from the witch's shoulder with reluctance. But come down he did, responding to the command that passed between them the way the hand obeys the head.

He made a show of looking for crumbs on the floor as he hopped toward the messenger's bag.
[Continue.]
He swiftly undid the laces.
[Continue.]
The bag was open. He returned to the witch.
[Continue.]

<FirstName> could see scrolls inside the satchel. What's more, <he/she> could see that one of them had the minister's seal. Astimund had done good work. It was practically identical to the forgery in the witch's possession.
[Continue.]
But now <FirstName> would have to extract the real letter and replace it with the fake.
Perhaps <FirstName> could use <his/her> cunning.
[Failure: Wisdom too low] Unfortunately, no opportunity for cunning revealed itself.
<FirstName> used <his/her> quickness.
[Prithee Sleep, Prithee Slumber] Witchcraft would be preferable to traditional espionage.
<FirstName> gave up. It was too risky. Astimund's plan would likely fail anyway.

[Success: Wisdom 15] <FirstName> took out the forgery and slipped it to Pharaoh. 
Then <he/she> pretended to get up. As <he/she> did, <he/she> knocked the messenger's drink onto the floor, not far from the satchel.
[Continue.]

Before the messenger could react, <FirstName> apologized and moved the satchel out of the way. The bag was open, so the messages spilled out. The young witch crouched down, mumbling apologies, and started picking them up and putting them back in the satchel.
[Continue.]
"You clumsy fool! What are you doing? No -- I can handle it. No, not like that -- let me do it."
[Continue.]
The messenger got down on her hands and knees. Pharaoh strutted across the floor toward her, the forgery in his beak.
[Continue.]

"Your bird has one of my messages!" she cried. 

The crow was all the distraction <FirstName> needed. <FirstName> spied the genuine letter to the princess and secreted it away.
"He's only trying to help."
"I don't need his help."
[Continue.]
The bird cocked his head.
[Continue.]
<FirstName>'s familiar dropped the forgery on the floor and flew back to <FirstName>'s shoulder. Cursing, the messenger retrieved the rest of the messages.
"You really shouldn't have put your cup so close to the table edge," <FirstName> chided.
The messenger scowled, stood up, and left, checking the satchel one last time before she did. All the messages were there -- or so she thought.
[Continue.]
[Continue.]
<FirstName> kept stammering apologies.
She accepted them with reluctance. She stood to go and checked her satchel one last time. All the messages were there -- or so she thought.
[Continue.]
[Continue.]
"So he does. If you give him a kernel, he'll give it back to you."
"I have a better idea. Why don't you give him a kernel?"
[Continue.]
But there was no need.
[Continue.]
Pharaoh dropped the forgery on the floor and flew back to <FirstName>'s shoulder. Cursing, the messenger retrieved the rest of the messages.

actions.a_parameter_1: Forged Letter of the Minister lost!

subNodes.conversationText: <FirstName> used <his/her> quickness.

[Failure: Dexterity too low] <FirstName> bent over as if to pick up something <he/she>'d dropped. He hoped to exchange the letters, but the messenger, perhaps suspicious, picked up the satchel and set it beside her.
[Continue.]
She soon stood up to go.
[Prithee Sleep, Prithee Slumber] But the young witch couldn't let her get away.
There was nothing the witch could do.

[Success: Dexterity 14] <FirstName> bent over as if to pick up something <he/she>'d dropped. With a flick of <his/her> wrist, <he/she> removed the forgery from his sleeve and planted it in the satchel. Then he nabbed the genuine letter.
[Continue.]
Still listening to the music, the messenger was none the wiser.
[Continue.]
A few minutes later, the messenger stood up. She took a quick inventory of her possessions, including the satchel, and left.
[Continue.]
[Continue.]
